courses.title: Installation and Setup
courses.description: This course guides you through the essential setup steps and introduces the core concepts
courses.review: I feel the setup instructions are clear and straightforward. I had initial confusion between traditional and standalone components.

courses.title: Traditional Components
courses.description: Discover how traditional Angular components shape your application's user interface.
courses.review: Traditional components felt organized and easy to follow. It was a good introduction to Angular's structure.

courses.title: Standalone Components
courses.description: Learn how standalone components simplify Angular development by removing the need for NgModules.
courses.review: Standalone components simplified the structure by removing the need for NgModules but took some time to get used to.

courses.title: Binding
courses.description: Dive into data binding in Angular and learn how it connects your application's logic to the user interface.
courses.review: Binding required some extra attention at first, I really had to focus on the difference between property and event binding.

courses.title: Dependency Injection
courses.description: Explore how Angularâ€™s dependency injection system simplifies code management and promotes modular design.
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Dependency Injection took a bit of time to understand, but once I understood how it interacted with components, it clicked.

courses.title: Observables
courses.description: You'll learn how Observables work under the hood, how to create and subscribe to them, and how they integrate with Angular services and HTTP requests.
courses.review: Observables were a challenging concept initially, but understanding how they interact with services made things clearer

courses.title: Interface
courses.description: Understand how interfaces in Angular help define the shape of data and enforce title safety. .
courses.review: Interfaces were one of the more straightforward topics. They helped define the structure of data and improved code consistency.
courses.codeSnippet: interface Course { title: string; duration: string; }

courses.title: Routing and Navigation
courses.description: Master Angularâ€™s routing and navigation system to build seamless, single-page applications..
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Routing took some practice. Once everything was connected properly, the flow made a lot more sense

courses.title: Reactive Forms
courses.description: Gain a deep understanding of reactive forms in Angular and how they enable dynamic, scalable form handling.
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Pretty straightforward and provides flexibility with dynamic inputs and validation.
courses.codeSnippet: this.form = new FormGroup({ name: new FormControl('') });

courses.title: RxJS Operators
courses.description: Unlock the power of RxJS operators to transform, filter, and manage streams of data in Angular.
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: RxJS Operators took some time to master, but learning to use map, switchMap, and mergeMap effectively made working with observables much easier

courses.title: Testing & Debugging
courses.description: Learn how to write effective tests and debug Angular applications with confidence. .
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Unit testing with Jasmine and Karma was easier than expected. Debugging tips were gold.

courses.title: Extras
courses.description: Explore additional Angular features including working with images, creating and using pipes, and handling advanced syntax.
courses.review: The Extras section was a great way to explore additional features like pipes and image handling.

steps: A new user story, bug, or feature is created in Azure Boards.
Work items are documented with a clear title, detailed description, and acceptance criteria.
The item is categorized (e.g., User Story, Bug, Task, Epic) based on the work type.
The team assigns a priority, sets the area and iteration paths, and adds relevant tags for classification.
The work item remains in this state until it is reviewed and approved for development.
The work item is reviewed by the team during backlog refinement meetings.
Effort is estimated using story points.
Acceptance criteria and requirements are validated and finalized.
The item is prioritized, approved, and marked as 'Ready for Development'.
Pull the latest updates from the main branch to ensure your environment is current.
Navigate to Azure Repos and create a new branch for your work.
Use the appropriate naming convention: 'feature/' for new functionality or 'bug/' for fixes.
Name the branch as: [user-story-id]-[three-word-description] (e.g., 1234-update-user-profile).
Fetch and switch to the new branch in VS Code using Git or terminal.
Begin development work in your local environment.
Use the QA environment link to simulate staging or test with QA-specific data.
Use Sales Agreement Numbers provided for QA testing, or query the database to generate them.
Preview your changes locally using the correct sales agreement to simulate a full user flow.
Run and ensure all unit tests pass before committing your changes.
Definition of Done (DoD): The user story must meet all acceptance criteria.
Commit your changes with a clear message and push the branch to Azure Repos.
Move the work item in Azure Boards to â€˜In Pull Requestâ€™.
Create a pull request (PR) in Azure Repos with the title format: WI [user story number] | [short title of user story].
Write a clear PR description using bullet points:
- What was changed (summary of implementation).
- How to test the changes (QA steps, specific data, or environment notes).
Peer Review Process:
- Teammates review the code, pull it locally if needed, and provide comments.
- If any issues are found, developers fix them and push changes to the same branch.
- Once all Code Review (CR) comments are addressed, the PR is approved and ready for merging.
PR has been approved and merged into the main or staging branch.
QA environment is updated with the latest changes.
Test cases are reviewed and confirmed with the QA team.
Test cases are reviewed with the QA team to ensure coverage of the user story and potential edge cases.
QA engineers validate the feature against the acceptance criteria.
If needed, regression testing is performed to ensure existing functionality is unaffected.
Any bugs found during QA are documented and linked back to the original work item or new bugs are created.
Once QA testing is complete and all issues are resolved, the item is marked as 'QA Passed'.
All relevant documentation (e.g., user guides, tech wikis) is reviewed and updated.
The work item has passed QA testing and satisfies all aspects of the team's Definition of Done (DoD).
The Azure Boards work item is marked as 'Done' to reflect completion.
